From: Margy Rochester [mailto:margyroc@gmail.com <mailto:margyroc@gmail.com>] Sent: Tuesday, March 26, 2013 10:34 AM To: Sara Conde Subject: question for you Hi Sara -
A quick question for you - I need to complete the enrollment process, and am considering the retirement plan and I want to make sure I understand this correctly.
If I elect to deduct an amount to go to the retirement plan (up to 50 %?), then there is a ~ 30 % retirement match that comes from the business center funds - i.e. it is from the portion of my income that goes into business center funds. From what I can see on the cash flow estimate you had given me, it appears that this amount is not subject to taxes, because it is deducted from the "total income/receipts". Taxes are then calculated on the Gross W-2 pay, correct? Yes, that’s correct.
It seems to me that it would be advantageous to maximize this amount, unless I am not understanding correctly how this works or I am missing something. Can you let me know if this all sounds right? I'd also be appreciative of your thoughts. Yes, there is real tax advantage to putting away this much income pretax and many our members take advantage of it. The one downside is cash flow as such a large part of your pay check would go into the 401(k) and not to your bank account. If cash flow is not a huge issue I would absolutely recommend taking advantage of fully maximizing. Remember, you can change this at any time, so my suggestion would be to start off with a lower percentage get a feel for your cash flow, and then up the percentage if desired. You can change it at any time in your account so there is no need to go “all-in” in the beginning unless you want to. thanks!
Margy
